content.question: For a one-sample test for a population proportion <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and sample size <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, why is it necessary that <math alttext="n times p sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math alttext="n times, open parenthesis, 1 minus p sub 0, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>(</mo><mtext>1</mtext><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are both at least 10 ?

choices.label: The sample size must be large enough to support an assumption that the distribution of the population is approximately normal.
The sample size must be large enough to support an assumption that the distribution of the sample is approximately normal.
The sample size must be large enough to support an assumption that the sampling distribution of the sample proportion is approximately normal.
The sample size must be large enough to support an assumption that the observations are independent.
The sample size must be large enough to support an assumption that the sample proportion is an unbiased estimator of the population proportion.

content.answer: The sample size must be large enough to support an assumption that the sampling distribution of the sample proportion is approximately normal.
